attributes.title: Acupuncture and manual therapy for rotator cuff tears a protocol of systematic review
attributes.description: The tears of rotator cuff is caused by the tears or aseptic inflammation of tendon tissue such as subscapular muscle, supraspinatus muscle, infraspinatus muscle, teres minor muscle, etc., which make up the rotator cuff. Managements of rotator cuff disease often include acupuncture and manual therapy, usually delivered together. The aim of this review is to assess the effectiveness and safety of such interventions in patients with pain and dysfunction caused by rotator cuff tears.

attributes.title: Syntactic Satiation and Adaptation to Speaker Identity: Part 2. Follow up with balanced stimuli set
attributes.description: This project investigates syntactic satiation effects and explores whether or not the "equalization strategy" can be used to account for the satiation of different island constructions.

name.value: Syntactic Satiation and Adaptation to Speaker Identity: Part 2. Follow up with balanced stimuli set

sample.value: A total of 240 participants will be recruited (120 participants per experiment). In experiment 1, each participant will see 1 of the 3 survey lists (a Latin Square design), with each list containing 98 trials (45 test items, and 53 filler items). In experiment 2, each participant will also see 1 of the 3 survey lists (a Latin Square design), with each list containing 75 trials (45 test items, and 30 filler items). For each experiment, each survey list will be assigned to 40 participants.

analyses.value: We will use a linear mixed effects model predicting acceptability ratings from fixed effects of presentation order, condition, and their interaction. Random by-participant and by-item intercepts will be included, as well as by-participant and by-item slopes for the fixed effects. Syntactic satiation will be detected as a positive main effect of presentation order or interactions between presentation order and condition.

outliers.value:
Participants will be excluded if:
(1) they reported their first language to be non-English;
(2) they entered incorrect responses for the practice questions more than once.
(3) the 95% CI of the responses to the ungrammatical word-salad fillers overlaps with the 95% CI of the responses to the grammatical fillers.

dependent.value: Participants will be asked to rate how "acceptable" each target sentence sound, and give their ratings by dragging a continuous slider. The left end of the scale is marked by "totally unacceptable", and the right end of the scale is marked by "totally acceptable". The position of the slider on the scale will be recorded as the acceptability judgment score (left end is 0, right end is 1, and everywhere else on the scale being evenly spread between 0 and 1).

conditions.value: There are three test conditions in total: subject-island violation, Complex-NP violation, and whether-island violation. Each participant will see a survey containing all three conditions (15 of each). In both experiments, grammatical and ungrammatical items are balanced. In experiment 1, island-violation items are considered as ungrammatical, and there are 45 island items, 4 ungrammatical word-salad fillers, and 49 grammatical fillers. In experiment 2, island-violation items are considered as neither grammatical nor ungrammatical, and there are 45 island items, 15 ungrammatical word-salad fillers, and 15 grammatical fillers.

hypothesis.value: Snyder (2000) observed that certain island violating constructions "satiate" ( exhibit increase in acceptability) when participants are exposed to a certain number of them. In a previous experiment, we replicated parts of the findings by Snyder (2000). In this study, we are testing if subject-island violation, Complex-NP violation, and whether-island violation exhibit satiation effect when the stimuli set is balanced between ungrammatical and grammatical items.

attributes.title: Changes to the Playing Field: Online Sports Betting Then and Now

summary.value: This is a pre-registration for the study "Changes to the Playing Field: Online Sports Betting Then and Now". The attached pre-registration provides detailed information about the data set, sample, design, and analytic plans for this study. The study is a data analysis of an existing set of records. The authors are in the process of obtaining these records, but have not yet analyzed any data from these files.

attributes.title: Online sports betting in the United States: A multilevel analysis of factors predicting the decision to bet
attributes.description: Following the Supreme Court ruling that overturned the Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act (PASPA) in 2018 (Murphy v. National Collegiate Athletic Ass’n, 2018), there has been increased sports betting opportunities for gamblers in the United States (U.S.) (American Gaming Association, 2019). Despite the growth of legal markets, illegal sports betting (mostly through unregulated offshore sites) is still deeply entrenched across the country, including jurisdictions where domestically-licensed sportsbooks operate (American Gaming Association, 2019). These illegal sites are a problem for governments for many reasons – they may lack regulatory oversight and consumer protection mechanisms, and often enable financial crimes like money laundering and tax evasion (Albanese, 2018). 	Understanding consumers’ motivations for using illegal online sportsbooks is essential in developing policies to discourage the use of illegal sites as well as to encourage use of legal ones. However, little is known about U.S. consumer motivation in selecting legal versus illegal online sportsbooks. Therefore, the primary goal of this study is to determine the main factors that draw U.S. consumers to place a bet on illegal online sportsbooks instead of legitimate ones. In addition, we will examine the differences in demographics and gambling behaviors of people choosing between illegal and legal sites. From this analysis, we hope to derive implications for developing sports betting regulation policies.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
Name: Online sports betting in the United States: A multilevel analysis of factors predicting the decision to bet.

Description: The primary goal of this study is to determine the main factors that draw U.S. consumers to place a bet on illegal online sportsbooks instead of legitimate ones. In addition, we will examine the differences in demographics and gambling behaviors of people choosing between illegal and legal sites. From this analysis, we hope to derive implications for developing sports betting regulation policies.

sample.value: We hope to obtain up to 1,000 respondents, depending on how many individuals reply to our recruitment efforts. This project employs an anonymous online survey to examine the consumers' motivations for using illegal online sportsbooks. Respondents will be recruited through advertisements placed on multiple U.S. online sports betting forums. Subjects recruited through the forums will be directed to the survey via a link that will take them to the Qualtrics survey site.

analyses.value:
We will first use descriptive statistics and simple means comparisons to determine how illegal online bettors differ from legal online sports bettors in the United States. Once we have provided a baseline understanding of differences, we will take a more advanced statistical approach and use a simple logistic regression to examine factors for choosing illegal sites and to compare illegal sports bettors with domestic ones. The use of logistic regression allows us to account for alternative explanations in online sports betting decisions – for example, we might find in our means comparisons that men are more likely to choose illegal sports books. In our logistic regression, we are able to examine the relationship between gender and sportsbook preferences while also accounting for things like education, age, or socioeconomic status. In doing so, we might find (again, for example) that men themselves demonstrate no preference, but instead that education matters. If women are more likely to have higher education levels than the male respondents and are more likely to gamble legally, ignoring education will provide misleading results.
  
After establishing foundational information, we plan to use hierarchical (also known as multilevel) regression models. Since we are collecting data from individuals nested within U.S. states, and are relying on a dichotomous dependent variable (i.e., whether the person gambles illegally or not), the most appropriate approach for analysis is to use hierarchical logistic regression modeling. Using such a statistical model (as opposed to traditional regression) will allow us to: 1) determine which factors distinguish sports bettors using illegal sites, 2) analyze variability between jurisdictions as well as between individuals (giving us a better sense of how much jurisdictional characteristics matter compared to individual characteristics), and 3) account for any jurisdictional effects on the probability of using illegal sites.

outliers.value: We do not anticipate outliers in our data, given that the survey questions naturally bound responses. However, there is a chance of measurement error resulting from "social desirability" biases, cognitive errors, acquiescent response biases, respondent burden, etc. We have embedded two attention checks in the survey to determine whether a respondent's data should be included. We will also look at response patterns carefully. A failure to respond accurately to the attention checks, high levels of nonresponse, or other indications of measurement bias are likely to result in an observation being excluded from the data.

dependent.value: The primary variable we are trying to predict is whether sports bettors gamble only on legal websites (i.e., websites that are licensed within their state of residence) or if they do any sports betting on illegal websites (either offshore websites or domestic websites located outside of their jurisdiction). To this end, we ask our respondents a series of questions about what online sportsbooks they patronize, their state of residence, and whether they have placed sports bets on sites outside of their jurisdiction. Using these questions in combination, we will identify people gambling on sites not licensed in their state (i.e., “illegal gamblers”) even if they were unaware that they were doing so.

conditions.value:
We are not using a randomized experimental design, instead opting for survey methods to assess one's decision to bet legally or illegally. 

Our primary independent variables of interest include the jurisdiction in which an individual resides, their frequency of/involvement in online gambling, knowledge about the licensing of the online sites they prefer, and why they prefer the sports betting sites that they do.

hypothesis.value:
The primary goal of this study is to determine the main factors that draw U.S. consumers to place a bet on illegal online sportsbooks instead of legitimate ones. In addition, we will examine the differences in demographics and gambling behaviors of people choosing between illegal and legal sites. From this analysis, we hope to derive implications for developing sports betting regulation policies.  

Specifically, research questions that will be explored in the proposed research include: 
1.	What are the main factors that encourage online sports bettors to use illegal versus legal online sports betting websites?
2.	Are there demographic and behavioral differences between U.S. bettors that use illegal as opposed to legal sites? 
3.	Do our findings vary by U.S. jurisdiction?

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

attributes.title: Adolescent E-cigarette Use: Is it renormalising traditional cigarette smoking?
attributes.description: Adolescent electronic cigarette (e-cigarette) use (“vaping”) has become a major public health concern, with particular focus on how e-cigarettes may facilitate transition into cigarette smoking. Therefore, the aim of this study is to examine whether the proliferation of adolescent e-cigarette use is renormalising or displacing traditional tobacco use using two nationally representative data sets.

q2.value:
1.	Overall, prevalence of smoking will decrease over time, while prevalence of vaping will increase. 
2.	Smoking prevalence decreases regardless of vaping status. That is, there is significant decreases in smoking among those who ever vaped and who do not; among those who vape frequently and among those who vaped occasionally.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The National Youth Tobacco Survey (NYTS) is an annual, nationally representative, self-administered survey of US middle and high school students aged 9 years and above. Sample selection uses a stratified, three stage cluster design, which proceeds probabilistically without replacement where a primary sampling unit (PSU) is selected within each stratum, a school within each PSU and classes within each school. Participation is voluntary for schools and students (see https://www. cdc.gov/tobacco/data_ statistics/surveys/nyts/index.htm for details).  As 30-day e-cigarette use was first included as an item in 2014, this analysis will use data from 2014 to 2019.

Monitoring the Future (MTF) is an annual, nationally representative questionnaire of drug use. It is administered in classrooms to 8th, 10th and 12th graders in 48 contiguous states in America. (see https://www.icpsr.umich.edu/icpsrweb/NAHDAP/series/35). It surveys nearly 50,000 American students in public and private secondary schools.  As 30 day e-cigarette use was first included as an item in 2015, we will use data from 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2018.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
The National Youth Tobacco Survey (NYTS) is an annual, nationally representative, self-administered survey of US middle and high school students aged 9 years and above. Sample selection uses a stratified, three stage cluster design, which proceeds probabilistically without replacement where a primary sampling unit (PSU) is selected within each stratum, a school within each PSU and classes within each school. Participation is voluntary for schools and students (see https://www. cdc.gov/tobacco/data_ statistics/surveys/nyts/index.htm for details).  As 30-day e-cigarette use was first included as an item in 2014, this analysis will use data from 2014 to 2019.

Monitoring the Future (MTF) is an annual, nationally representative questionnaire of drug use. It is administered in classrooms to 8th, 10th and 12th graders in 48 contiguous states in America. (see https://www.icpsr.umich.edu/icpsrweb/NAHDAP/series/35). It surveys nearly 50,000 American students in public and private secondary schools.  As 30 day e-cigarette use was first included as an item in 2015, we will use data from 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2018.

Both surveys are publicly available.

q11.value:
NYTS: samples range from 17 711 in 2015 to 22 007 in 2014
MTF: samples range from 12, 600  in 2016 to 14, 502 in 2018

question.value:
NYTS:
Exposure. Two variables of e-cigarette use will be assessed. Ever use of e-cigarettes will be measured with the item, “Have you ever tried an electronic cigarette or e-cigarette, even one or two puffs?” with a response option of yes or no. E-cigarette use frequency will be defined with the item “During the past 30 days, on how many days did you use electronic cigarettes?” Participants were asked to report the number of days, which will be recoded into 1 of 3 categories (0 days [never], 1-19 days [occasional], 20-30 days [frequent]). Frequent use will defined as using an e-cigarette 20 to 30 days during the past 30 days. Occasional use will be defined as 1-19 days and never use will be defined as 0 days during the past 30 days. 

Outcome. Ever use of tobacco cigarettes will be measured with the item “Have you ever tried a cigarette, even a puff or two?” with a response option of yes or no. Tobacco cigarette dependency will be defined with the item “During the past 30 days, on how many days did you smoke cigarettes?” Frequent use will be defined as using an e-cigarette 20 to 30 days during the past 30 days. Infrequent use will be defined as 0-19 days during the past 30 days (0 days [never], 1-19 days [occasional], 20-30 days [frequent]).

MTF:
Exposures
In the MTF, participants will be classified as “ever users” if they responded with “once or twice” “occasional, but not regularly” “regularly in the past” or “regularly now” to “Have you ever used an electronic vaporizer such as an e-cigarette?” 

We will divide frequency of use into three categories.  This will produce an exposure variable for dependency. E-cigarette dependency will be defined with the item “During the last 30 days, on how many occasions (if any) have you used electronic cigarettes?” Participants are asked to report the number of days, which will be recoded into 1 of 3 categories (0 days [never], 1-19 days [occasional], 20-30 days [frequent]).

Outcomes 
Participants were asked “Have you ever smoked cigarettes?” This will be divided into a dichotomous variable. Those who responded with "once or twice" “occasional, but not regularly” “regularly in the past” or “regularly now” will be classified as “ever cigarette smokers”. Those who responded with “never” will be classified as “never cigarette smokers”. 

Participants were also asked “How frequently have you smoked cigarettes during the past 30 days?” to produce another outcome variable. Those who responded with “one to five cigarettes per day”, “about one half pack per day”, “about one and one-half packs per day” or “two packs or more per day”, will be classified as “heavy” smokers. Those who responded with “not at all” or “less than one cigarette per day” will be considered as “light” smokers.

All analyses will be performed with version 15.0 of Stata MP software20. The svyset: command will be used to take into account the weights, clustering (PSU), and stratum of the complex sampling design. In order to determine the association between various parameters, Pearson’s chi-square analysis for the cross tabulation and logistic regression analysis will be carried out for various combinations. Odds ratios, risk ratios and 95% confidence intervals (CI) for smoking will be calculated. We will test for a slope change in the rate of cigarette smoking among those who use e-cigarettes. Differences in prevalence across years will be assessed using designed based F-statistics.

registration_responses.q2:
1.	Overall, prevalence of smoking will decrease over time, while prevalence of vaping will increase. 
2.	Smoking prevalence decreases regardless of vaping status. That is, there is significant decreases in smoking among those who ever vaped and who do not; among those who vape frequently and among those who vaped occasionally.
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11:
NYTS: samples range from 17 711 in 2015 to 22 007 in 2014
MTF: samples range from 12, 600  in 2016 to 14, 502 in 2018

attributes.title: Emotion Regulation as a Resilience Factor For Internalizing Symptoms Following Early Adversity
attributes.description:
Early adversity (EA) can have deleterious impacts on one's well being. Specifically, being exposed to EA puts an individual at risk for atypical brain development as well as an increased susceptibility for the development of mood disorders later in life (Cicchetti & Toth, 2005; Green et al. 2010; Kessler et al. 2010; Keyes et al. 2018; McLaughlin et al. 2010; Nusslock and Miller 2016; Pechtel and Pizzagalli 2011). For example, previously institutionalized youth (PI; youth who experienced orphanage care and were subsequently adopted) are at increased risk for internalizing disorders relative to their comparison (i.e., youth raised by their biological parents since birth) peers. 

Cognitive reappraisal is an emotion regulation strategy that involves changing one’s interpretation of emotional events and has been shown to be an important component of healthy social-emotional development in adolescents and adults (Cutuli 2014; Haga et al. 2009). Expressive suppression, by contrast, involves suppressing the outward expression of emotion and has been linked to decreased well-being (Cutuli 2014; Haga et al. 2009). Both cognitive reappraisal and expressive suppression involve the down-regulation of emotion, however, their underlying processes and consequences are drastically different. Here we assessed the role of these two widely-studied emotion regulation strategies, cognitive reappraisal and expressive suppression on the development of internalizing psychopathology (anxiety, depression, somatic complaints, and withdrawal) among PI versus comparison youths. 

While EA is a strong predictor for the development of psychopathology, less is known about what makes PI youth resilient. The present study sought to investigate whether engaging in effortful emotion regulation, such as cognitive reappraisal, would buffer PI youth against internalizing symptomatology compared to comparison youth. Identifying risk and resilience factors that modify links between EA and psychopathology is critical in order to optimize treatments tailored to the affected population.

q1.value: Yael Waizman, Adriana Mendez Leal, Joao F. Guassi Moreira, Natalie Saragosa-Harris, Emilia Ninova, Jennifer Silvers

q2.value:
We hypothesize that EA in the form of a history of orphanage care would predict higher internalizing symptomatology in children and adolescents compared to youth raised by their biological parents. 

Given that emotion regulation, such as cognitive reappraisal has been previously linked to positive mental health outcomes, we hypothesize that greater cognitive reappraisal usage would attenuate links between PI status and internalizing symptoms. Specifically, that (1) EA-exposed individuals who engage in cognitive reappraisal will show fewer internalizing symptoms, (2) cognitive reappraisal usage will negatively correlate with internalizing psychopathology in both the PI and comparison groups, and (3) expressive suppression usage will correlate positively with internalizing psychopathology across both PI and comparison groups. 

We further predict that two emotion regulation strategies will exert opposing moderating influences on the relationship between EA exposure and internalizing symptoms. Specifically, we hypothesize that the relationship between PI status and greater internalizing symptomatology will depend upon the type of emotion regulation strategy individuals report engaging in more when facing an emotionally elicited event. Such that, this relationship will be stronger for those who utilize expressive suppression and weaker among individuals who employ cognitive reappraisal.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study has a cross-sectional design.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: Data collection was completed on 3/7/20. No analyses have been run on the existing data.

question.value:
Participants: In total, 36 PI youths (23 girls and 13 boys; mean age = 14.47, SD = 1,92, range = 9-17) and 58 comparison youths (32 girls and 26 boys; mean age = 13.24, SD = 2.13, range = 9-17) participated in this study. Each youth’s caregiver participated in the study by completing child-report measures. 

Recruitment/Inclusion/Exclusion Criteria: Participants were recruited as part of a larger longitudinal study examining the long term effects of EA on brain, immune, behavioral, social, and emotional development. Participants were pulled from that larger sample based on their age (due to the use of caregiver report on internalizing psychopathology) and their completion of the two measures of interests (Emotion Regulation Questionnaire - Youth and Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL/6-18)). Comparison youth (non-internationally adopted children and adolescents raised by their biological parents) were prescreened for any diagnoses of behavioral or psychological concerns, or learning disabilities. Any comparison youth who was diagnosed with any of these did not participate in the study. The inclusion criteria for PI youth was being internationally adopted from an institutional care or a foster care setting. No exclusion criteria were made based on race or ethnicity. However, because many of the children who have been adopted from other countries were born in Asia, efforts were made to match comparisons based on ethnic background. All participants were fluent in English and resided in the United States during the duration of the study and completed all testing sessions at the University of California, Los Angeles. This study was approved by the university's Institutional Review Board. Both participants and their caregivers provided informed assent and consent prior to the completion of the study. 

Compensation: All participants were compensated $20 for participating in this portion of our study. Caregivers earned $10 for completing child-report measures.

q11.value: In total, 94 children and adolescents (36 PI and 58 comparison youths) participated in this study.

q12.value: The target sample size for the overall longitudinal study was 150, but a target was not set for this substudy. The sample size for this study is consistent with prior reports focused on early adversity in developmental populations (Silvers et al. 2016; Tottenham et al. 2010).

question.value:
Predictor variables: 
- Early Adversity (EA): The presence of EA exposure was indexed based on being internationally adopted from orphanages. Those who were raised by their biological parents and were not previously institutionalized were placed in the comparison group. 
- Participants completed the Emotion Regulation Questionnaire (ERQ) - Youth (Gullone, 2012) to assess the use of two emotion regulation strategies, cognitive reappraisal, and expressive suppression. This questionnaire was adapted from Gross & John, 2003. 
Covariates: 
- Due to the PI group having more females as well as older participants than the comparison group, gender and age will be included as covariates for ERQ in all analyses. 
Outcome variables: 
- Caregivers completed the Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL/6-18) to assess internalizing symptomatology (anxiety, depression, somatic complaints, and withdrawal) in their children. Standardized internalizing t-scores will be calculated in relation to norms for each gender and age. Therefore, age and gender will not be included as covariates for this outcome variable.

Three Pearson product-moment correlation coefficients will be computed to assess the relationships between (1) EA and internalizing psychopathology, (2) cognitive reappraisal and internalizing psychopathology, and (3) expressive suppression and internalizing psychopathology. 

Additionally, a linear regression will be conducted with the following:
Dependent variable: 
- Internalizing psychopathology 
Main Effects: 
- Emotion regulation strategies (e.g., cognitive reappraisal and expressive suppression) 
- PI status which will be coded dichotomously (e.g., Dummy coding, PI youth = 1, Comparison youth = 0)
Interaction Terms:
- PI status X Cognitive Reappraisal 
- PI status X Expressive Suppression
Covariates for emotion regulation strategies:
- Gender which will be coded dichotomously (e.g., Dummy coding, M = 1, F = 2)
- Age

q19.value: Results with p-values less than 0.05 will be regarded as being statistically significant. While p-values within the range of 0.05 and 0.10 will be considered as being marginally significant. All analysis will be two-tailed.

q20.value: The 94 participants were pulled out of a larger longitudinal study based on their age (9-17-year-olds). This was done in order to examine our hypotheses only for those participants that completed both measures of interests (CBCL/6-18 and ERQ-Y). Thus, participants from the larger sample that were 18 years or older were excluded from this study as they did not have any caregiver report measures collected.

q21.value: This study only included subjects that had all measures of interest (CBCL/6-18 and ERQ-Y). None of our 94 participants had any missing data on these two questionnaires.

q22.value: We may also examine the relationship between emotion regulation and age. Specifically, (1) whether expressive suppression and cognitive reappraisal track with age and (2) whether this relationship differs for PI versus comparison youth.

registration_responses.q1: Yael Waizman, Adriana Mendez Leal, Joao F. Guassi Moreira, Natalie Saragosa-Harris, Emilia Ninova, Jennifer Silvers

We hypothesize that EA in the form of a history of orphanage care would predict higher internalizing symptomatology in children and adolescents compared to youth raised by their biological parents. 

Given that emotion regulation, such as cognitive reappraisal has been previously linked to positive mental health outcomes, we hypothesize that greater cognitive reappraisal usage would attenuate links between PI status and internalizing symptoms. Specifically, that (1) EA-exposed individuals who engage in cognitive reappraisal will show fewer internalizing symptoms, (2) cognitive reappraisal usage will negatively correlate with internalizing psychopathology in both the PI and comparison groups, and (3) expressive suppression usage will correlate positively with internalizing psychopathology across both PI and comparison groups. 

We further predict that two emotion regulation strategies will exert opposing moderating influences on the relationship between EA exposure and internalizing symptoms. Specifically, we hypothesize that the relationship between PI status and greater internalizing symptomatology will depend upon the type of emotion regulation strategy individuals report engaging in more when facing an emotionally elicited event. Such that, this relationship will be stronger for those who utilize expressive suppression and weaker among individuals who employ cognitive reappraisal.

q2.value: It is hypothesized that there will be a main effect of the audience such that participants under the impression that their friends can see their answers will report drinking more than those under the impression that their parents can see their answers.  It is also hypothesized that since women metabolize alcohol slower, they will drink less so women will report less drinks than men. The final hypothesis is that there will be an interaction, such that males who are under the impression that their friends can see their results will report more drinks than females who are under the impression that their friends can see their results.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: I am sending a link out through social media for participants to follow. They fill out the survey including demographics and two between-subject variables that determine whether sex and either parents or friends looking at responses determine reported drinking behavior. Participants will either receive a question asking about the last number of their phone number which will determine if they receive the factor of their parents being able to see the results or their friends.

q11.value: Ideally, I will have 20 per between-subject groups for a total of 40 participants.

q12.value: My professor said to get 20 per between-subject group and since I have two variables, I need 40 participants.

q13.value: I plan to stop collecting data once I have enough participants.

question.value: Whether the participants think their parents can see their reported drinking behavior or if their friends can see their reported drinking behavior.
Sex (male or female) and my DV (On average, how many drinks do you have on a night out?)
I will collect means of the different variables to be able to compare them.
ANOVA to check for interaction between friends/parents and/or sex and reported drinking behavior.

attributes.title: Impact of the HIT on  the communication between cancer patients and care providers in clinical settings
attributes.description: The purpose of this study is to conduct a systematic review of existing evidence to explore studies reporting the impact of any type of health information technologies (EHR, Apps, portals maybe later, telehealth not included) on communication and communication outcomes in oncology visits.
tags: Communication between patients and healthcare providers

q2.value: We conduct a systematic review of existing evidence to explore studies reporting the impact of any type of health information technologies (EHR, Apps, portals maybe later, telehealth not included) on communication and communication outcomes in oncology visits.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: No existing data is being used.

question.value:
Search Strategy

We searched published literature database using free texts and Mesh terms pertaining to the concepts of technology-based solutions, tools and strategies and the communications between cancer patients and providers. If there is a limit on the number of search terms that a database can search, the most relevant terms are employed with predefined combinations. Where possible, English-language forms and syntax limits are set.

1)	Database:
i.	PubMed
ii.	Web of Science
iii.	Cochrane Library (CENTRAL)
iv.	IEEE Xplore
 
We also conducted a cross check search in some journals like Journal of health communication and Journal of cancer informatics.
2)	Hand search reference list
Eligible documents located through the database searches.

4 filters are applied to the results of the search. First, the extraction of the articles which is based on the Mesh words predefined. Second, the filter of the redundant articles in which database separately and the third filtering the repeted articles between the databases. The last filter is based on the exclusion and inclusion criteria set.


Database Searching Notes
The databases listed above have different search capabilities in terms of keywords and subject headings. We use the most rigorous approach possible for each database.

To help develop our search strategies, in March 2020 a pilot search was performed in the databases above. 8989 documents were retrieved and screened for relevance. Subject headings and keywords were harvested from relevant documents and used to help develop comprehensive search strategies. When looking up subject headings, tree structures were consulted to assess whether broader or narrower terms should be included. The proposed final search strategy was run to ensure all of the relevant documents identified by the preliminary major concept search would also be identified by our final search strategy.

Screening/Study Selection
Software
Document information are uploaded from each database into Zotero. This tool can detect duplicate documents if the title, year and volume information match exactly; one document is retained for screening and the other is excluded. Additionally, duplicates may be identified during level 1 screening. If so, reviewers attach a ‘duplicate’ tag to one of the documents and mark it for exclusion.

Level 1: Title and Abstract
In level screening, the document’s title and/or abstract will be reviewed. To be included in the title/abstract must 1) identify the document as reporting on a quantitative research study, 2) mention or allude to the use of technology, and 3) indicate some cancer patient communication outcomes.

Two team members (Elkefi and Asan) together review all the publications for eligibility with consensus. They rate each document as ‘Include’, ‘Exclude’, or ‘maybe’ with respect to the above criteria. Documents where both reviewers say ‘Include’, or ‘maybe’ with consensus, will pass to level two screening. Rest will be excluded. Documents where one reviewer answers ‘Include’ or ‘maybe’ and the other answers ‘Exclude’ will be considered a disagreement. 

Level 2: Full Text
Two reviewers will together review the full text of all documents that make it past the level 1 screening. To be included, documents must meet all eligibility criteria as outlined below.

Eligibility Criteria

Inclusion and exclusion Criteria: 
•	Published between January 2009 and March 2020
•	Contains cancer or oncology studies
•	Discusses communication between provider-patient (Exclusion: provider-provider communication/team communication)
•	Technology should be obvious (Exclusion, if it is talking on tools such as PRO or surveys without technology, not included)
•	We include both person communication and e-communication
•	Outcome measures: Papers must report communication outcomes quantitatively or qualitatively, we might include outcomes related to patient engagement, patient understanding and empowerment since they are also related to communication.
•	Conceptual papers should not be included. (without data collection)
•	The environment might be both outpatient clinic and inpatient settings (such as ICU etc.)
•	The data might come from either patient or providers. it might be observation, chart review etc.
This is an observational study: literature review
No variables are being used that can be measured.

An initial data extraction form is created in Excel; a preliminary outline of information to be included is listed below but will be reviewed and revised as necessary after relevant full text articles have been identified. Extraction will be compared and discussed to ensure all relevant information for the research question is captured in a consistent manner. Revisions to the form will be made as needed.

1)	authors and year of publication
2)	aims, and objectives of the study,
3)	methods
4)	findings

Organizing and Reporting the Results
Results will be organized and reported in a way that satisfies the purpose of our review, however, specifics will not be determined until we have a better idea of what the relevant literature looks like.

registration_responses.q2: We conduct a systematic review of existing evidence to explore studies reporting the impact of any type of health information technologies (EHR, Apps, portals maybe later, telehealth not included) on communication and communication outcomes in oncology visits.
registration_responses.q3: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q9: No existing data is being used.
registration_responses.q6.question: Please see the file attached.
